Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: High Energy-Density Hydrogen-Halogen Flow Batteries for Energy Storage
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is the development of a high energy density, low-cost energy storage technology. Affordable long duration energy storage is critical to the wide adoption of renewable power. This is a growing market segment which is underserved by current (e.g., lithium-ion battery) storage technologies. Energy storage can be of importance in rural communities where the impacts of power disruption are severe. This project seeks to develop energy storage that, when paired with solar or wind renewable power, is cheaper than fossil fuel-based generation. Such a development would accelerate the transition to a modern clean energy economy, would reduce the environmental impacts of power generation, and would increase the economic resilience of rural communities.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project proposes to develop an electrochemical energy storage device. Flow batteries are a compelling option for long-duration energy storage, as the energy storage (chemicals in tanks) is decoupled from the power delivery (in an electrochemical cell). A major hurdle for flow batteries has been the high cost of the chemicals used for storage (e.g., vanadium). This Phase I project develops a flow battery that makes use of commonly available and high energy density hydrogen and halogen chemical compounds. The project extends this flow battery technology into new concentration and fluid dynamical regimes that will enable commercial scaling of the technology. This project also tests novel bipolar plates made from modern composite materials, examining their suitability as low-cost, long lifespan cell components in commercial production. Laboratory efforts are complemented by the development of validated numerical models which will be used to optimize cell design. These laboratory experiments and validated numerical models in the high halogen concentration regime will open new windows for electrochemical energy storage at community and grid scales.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Skip Technology's NSF SBIR Phase I was focused on developing a novel membrane cell for a flow battery. This battery will be able to store energy cheaply, not discharge during storage and containerize easily for manufacturing, transportation and installation. Additionally, the project also was used to advance the theoretical model software that initially predicted our solution by matching predictions to experimental results.

If this research is fully successful and the novel battery proves capable in the field, it would significantly change the energy storage market. Our cost prediction is that solar and/or wind renewable energy could be generated and stored (by our battery) for less than the cost of any carbon fuel. This would create free-market incentives for power producers to switch to renewable energy and save American consumers money at the same time.

The Phase I was successful. All our proposed tasks were completed. Our experimental results did differ from our initial predictions, but not significantly, and the differences were found to be additional nuances that the model did not account for. Once these additions were incorporated into the prediction software, the model and experiment agreed well.

The membrane cell research to date shows that our initial predictions that it will form the core of an extremely efficient, cost-effective flow battery are, to date, correct. While further development must occur before it is ready for commercial use, we have already advanced the technology significantly along that path.
